smoke maybe secondhand but it can kill

some call it the number one indoor air pollutant one thing is for sure secondhand smoke is present anytime someone lights up a cigarette cigar or pipe and when non-smokers are exposed to that secondary smoke many have immediate negative reactions the eyes begin the normal biological response to your rotation which is they become inflamed and they water what about nausea and headaches that's often the response to the irritation and inflammation

nation of both the eyes and the sinuses but tobacco industry spokesperson say those reactions may be due to other invisible air pollutants smoking is the only thing in the end or are you can see so people tend to blame it for their watery eyes many times it's the lack of humidity it's the chemicals in the air from the mold in the ventilation of the carpet or the wall coverings to some people it just smells plain bad and in fact there's literature in the scientific

richer that talks about a psychosomatic reaction to tobacco smoke that is I don't like it therefore I'm going to react very strongly it is not a psychosomatic reaction when you get this immediate tearing and what not when you don't even know where the source of the exposure is necessarily scientists have done studies where they've exposed people to secondhand smoke and measured these kind of irritant effects when the people didn't really know they were being exposed to secondhand smoke doctor

and says the irritations are a reaction to the chemicals burning in the tobacco once it's lighted 4,000 chemicals including 200 known poisons substances we would normally avoid ingesting some of them that you've heard of our ammonia which is toilet bowl cleaner formaldehyde which used to pickle dead things nicotine which in addition to being the addictive drug in tobacco is a potent insecticide napthalene which is mothballs haeju

Xena's Rocket Fuel Cyanide and arsenic is rat poison benzo a pyrene and dimethyl dimethyl Benzene answer seen our diesel fumes the list is just very long it goes on and on scientists have long known the dangers of mainstream smoke that which is inhaled by the smoker the fact is 400,000 Americans smokers die each year from diseases related to their smoking but now scientists say the

smoke curling from the lighted tip of a cigarette sidestream smoke is even more dangerous sidestream smoke clearly because it's burned at the lower temperatures produces more of the toxic and carcinogenic substances the major difference however is that that sidestream smoke is diluted in a much larger volume of air the environment in which everyone is living and breathing in contrast to the mainstream smoke which is delivered relatively

diluted into the smokers lungs that last point that sidestream smoke is diluted in the air is about the only issue over which the tobacco industry would agree and is used as one defense that a smoke-filled room is not dangerous to the nonsmoker the smoke and a room where they're over there smoking occurring is talks a logically different in the exposure is different because the chemistry is changed the minute the smoke hits the air and so the non-smokers exposed to something that's very

a friend then the smoker is and in a vastly diluted quantity than the smoker is it's true no one is sure what level of exposure to tobacco smoke will cause cancer but scientists say it's a game of Russian Roulette as far as we know for cancer there's no threshold for a fact there's no safe level of exposure cancer can be caused by one hit of any carcinogen and that and that clearly there's a dose-response relationship and then

the more you're exposed to the greater your risk the health risks associated with passive smoke were made known in the 1986 surgeon general's report it linked secondary smoke to lung cancer and healthy non-smokers said young children exposed to parental smoking have increased respiratory problems and separation of smokers and non-smokers in the same airspace reduces but does not eliminate the exposure to non-smokers other respected scientific councils have the same

certainly the consensus of the scientific Community as expressed by the World Health Organization as expressed by the national a national research Council and their report and as expressed by the US surgeon general's report is that this is absolutely with scientific certainty and environmental carcinogens secondary smoke are carcinogen in other words a cancer-causing agent responsible

Beaufort 22,000 new cancer cases every year seven thousand of those in people who never smoked the Environmental Protection Agency says 3700 non-smokers will die of lung cancer every year how does it happen scientists say when the tiny particles that make up tobacco smoke enter the lungs the response to their presence is irritation inflammation and ultimately to those agents that occurs magellanic a change in the actual

sell that lines the airway or is in the alveolus they causes it to lose its ability to stop growing and therefore become a cancer the cancerous cell multiplies probably at a rate of something doubles every hundred days or so in size so you start off with one single abnormal cell and old for about a 10-year period of so you develop a nodule that may then be detectable on a chest x-ray

three and then of course because we're talking about doubling growth after that is quite rapid the strongest evidence that I have is really seeing patients with lung cancer whose only exposure to any kind of carcinogen is exposure to smoke of others dr. munzer a spokesman for the American Lung Association says lung cancer has virtually no symptoms in its earliest stages and is the hardest cancer to detect

any lung cancers he says are found by chance on a routine x-ray such was the case of a 54 year-old woman who never smoked but suddenly develop seizures her problem was brain cancer that had spread from an undetected lesion in her lung there's this little extra Shadow and this extra Shadow actually turned out to be a lung cancer and in this next x-ray which was just taken the same woman just taken about two and a half

half months later and can everybody can tell now that this cancer really has grown tremendously and in fact she really she died or shortly after this x-ray was taken the woman the only exposure to tobacco smoke was on the job as a newspaper editor for she had worked all of her adult life as a journalist in smoke-filled newsrooms she kept questioning me and say you know but I'm not a smoker how could I possibly have developed this disease

it's difficult enough to explain lung cancer to a smoker but it's even more difficult to explain it to a person who is a nonsmoker what happened to Mother's patient is not uncommon according to Lawrence garfinkel an epidemiologist and spokesman for the American Cancer Society his study of non-smoking women long time married to men who smoked showed a 30 percent increased risk of lung cancer in our study for example the risk of women getting
lung cancer who was married to a smoker

increased in proportion to the number of cigarettes of husband smoke a day at home and in women whose husbands smoke at least 20 cigarettes a day at home the risk was at least twice as high as that of women who never smoked and were married to men who never smoked it's not just adults who suffer from the consequences of passive smoke the Environmental Protection Agency says 9 to 12 million American children are exposed to environmental tobacco smoke from parental so

taking these children have increased inner ear infections and they especially infants have a 200 to 400 percent increased risk of deep chest infections like bronchitis and pneumonia serious health problems at an early age that have equally serious consequences as they grow older the most important cause of the developed for the development of lung disease in adults is smoking the second most important cause Is frequent respiratory

actions during childhood and now we know that those frequent respiratory infections are usually the result of Parental smoking when they give these give these children tests of their lung function where they have them breathe into machines that can test how their lungs are doing that they don't perform as well as the children of non-smoking parents we know from the available literature base that there is some small decrement in lung function

as the loan matures in other words you actually have some stunting of the lung growth and those kids who have been exposed Joplin also cites data from a recent report in the New England Journal of Medicine children raised in households where one or both parents smoke have twice the risk of developing lung cancer as an adult even if they themselves never smoked when you expose those kids not only a during infancy through adolescence early adulthood that those that are heavily exposed I think it was

five pack years or greater you can get slightly more than a doubling of their lung cancer death rate as an adult but the tobacco industry claims the report is not supported by good or complete science there was a small yet statistically significant increase in risk and that's what the media is latched onto but that increase in Risk understand is based on reports by adults in their 19 they're in their 60s we're

hoarding about what they recall to be their childhood exposure to tobacco smoke in the home are not reliable the author's themselves question the reliability of the data and so here we have a study with 10 negative findings with more reliable data one positive finding with very unreliable data and yet it's made out to be this great scientific discovery frankly it's not they would like to treat this issue as if we had no knowledge of

tobacco smoke the size of the relative risk is what you would expect from extrapolating from a dose-response relationship downward from the active smoker two individuals were exposed to environmental tobacco smoke so the size of the relative risk is exactly what you would expect it is small it is small but it is significant it is enormously significant because of the number of individuals in our society that are exposed long

cancer isn't the only disease that concerns scientists dr. Stanton glance the author of a recently published study on environmental tobacco smoke estimates 37 thousand deaths from heart attacks each year in non-smokers his study of spouses concludes a 30 percent increased risk of heart attack among non-smokers living with smokers he explains how passive smoke inhibits the hearts action first of all Second Hand Smoke contains a lot of carbon monoxide carbon monoxide is

is a colorless odorless poison gas which binds to the blood and reduces its ability to carry oxygen the heart needs a lot of oxygen and if you're already compromised because of pre-existing disease you need all the oxygen you can get secondly the nicotine in the secondhand smoke has many effects on the cardiovascular system first of all it's a cardiac poison it actually makes the muscle work less effectively secondly it's what's called a vasoconstrictor it

makes heart but blood vessels and other blood vessels get smaller so if you have narrowed arteries on your heart because of heart disease and you make them smaller because of the nicotine that's going to increase the chances that you'll get a blockage which is what leads to a heart attack surfaces of the inside of arteries of actually become rough and irregular we believe because of exposure to things like carbon monoxide and some of the other really toxic substances in smoke another

a really important factor related to smoking and getting coronary disease is the effect of tobacco smoke on platelet activity and as you know platelets are the sticky substances in the blood that cause your blood to clot and to Clump that's a normal function however if you have an irregular surface in your arterial wall and it collects platelets around it it can actually cause the vessel to close down or to have spasm around the place where the

plump has built up dr. backer caution is that exposure to tobacco smoke further aggravates the risk of a heart attack especially if the nonsmoker also has high cholesterol high blood pressure eat a high fat diet does not exercise and has a family history of heart disease doctor Becker's colleague at Johns Hopkins dr. Scott Stewart says many times exposure to passive smoke is a factor in his patients needing heart surgery and perhaps three to five percent

the population that we see coming to cardiac surgery who will have a certain number of risk factors where you could understand how they would develop coronary artery disease but yet they seem to have gone under and developed a more aggressive form of the disease if you will or at the time of surgery you find that their vessels are a little more involved and you would have suspected and it is very common to find that other people in the house smoke even though the patient does not

many times exposure to pass a smoke is not at home but at the workplace dr. glance was recently involved in a case where a California man a vegetarian nonsmoker with no family history of heart disease suffered a heart attack after aru be attributed the illness to his on-the-job exposure as a waiter in a restaurant were smoking was allowed the place used to get very busy running boards 8:00 or 9:00 and I would say it on but 60% of people in their place smoke and they had

a poor ventilation and the kitchen was right there in the dining room and a lot of the smoke was coming out of the kitchen plus the cigarette smoke so the very poor quality of are the California Compensation Insurance Fund agreed with ob and will pay for his medical expenses which total about 85,000 dollars so if environmental tobacco smoke poses real health risks why isn't it regulated by the government brand-new Mellie chairman of the Coalition on smoking or health says tobacco

is Exempted from Federal Regulation she says even the additives and tobacco are unrestricted by the federal Congress has chosen not to use any of the authorities to regulate food products drugs consumer products they have not used any of those authorities in fact they've Exempted tobacco from all of those authorities in the past if they Exempted very powerful Lobby on the part of the tobacco industry the tobacco industry has used its

influencing other legislative areas as well Hef ologist dr. Leo Roth says under the new Clean Air Act the smoke coming from this or any other Smoke Stack has more regulations than the smoke from a lighted cigarette the average amount of smoke that a smoker puts into 10 by 10 office would not be allowed to come out of a smokestack of a public incinerator under EPA regulations and yet why is it allowed to come out of a cigarette it's a very interesting phenomenon the tobacco Lobby

he has been able to exempt the carcinogens that are otherwise regulated if they come from tobacco smoke Roth tests are samples for the EPA and works with private businesses searching for indoor air pollutants the sources of the so-called sick building syndrome this this can be made as a result of the release of certain organic solvents or other chemicals from building materials like formaldehyde it can be the result of Simply poor ventilation and accumulation of carbon dioxide you can

monoxide but it's been shown in all of these indoor air quality studies in which these are samples analyzed chemically that tobacco smoke is a number one pollutants and Roth an environmental tobacco smoke is so pervasive in everyday American life that pathologist can measure traces of it in most people probably so widespread that it's difficult to find individuals in today's society who do not have some quote Nina their urine indicated that at some time

in their daily activities they do get exposed to tobacco smoke because all of us are exposed to some amount of passive smoke in our everyday activities the Environmental Protection Agency charged with protecting the Public's Health has been investigating the effects of second-hand smoke on the nonsmoker its report labels passive smoke a group a or very hazardous human carcinogen joining the list which includes asbestos radon and Benzene staff scientist Steve Bayard says the conclusion followed a review of
24 studies on passive smoke together the trends for increasing cancer with increasing dose of environmental tobacco smoke

plus the consistency of Association the consistency that there is always lung cancer showing up in these studies positive associations with them together with the evidence the other evidence that we have on cigarette smoke the knowledge of the individual components in cigarette smoke as let us the staff to believe that we have sufficient evidence to declare this material no-cost antigen to humans the reports data has been reviewed by the epa's science Advisory Board

that hearing various scientific experts gave their opinions including dr. Maurice lavoie a tobacco industry consultant lavoie says the EPA Studies have not conclusively shown an association between passive smoke and cancer he says to go the next step and say there's a risk of getting cancer is not supported by scientific fact but by belief I think that that's consistent with what a lot of the writing has has implied here which is that if smoking is bad for you then exposure to someone else

that smoke is bad for you as well my response is that's a hypothesis not every single study has controls for each of these issues that is true across all epidemiologic data however when one looks at the studies that have tightly-controlled for those verbs that have looked for errors and classification that have looked for Miss classification of lung cancer they did work for some of the other variables that could explain a false result

those studies still show a significant Association after you take those factors into account and the tobacco industry's criticism of the research got an even stronger response from Health and Human Services secretary Louis Sullivan I say that's poppycock the tobacco companies constantly try to dismiss very solid scientific Studies by many scientists all over the country there is not a

spectable scientists in our country who accept that argument from the tobacco companies but lavoie cited statistics showing an increase in lung cancer cases among smokers but no change in cases of non-smokers if you look at what what has happened in the United States and vital statistics on lung cancer over the last four decades the the incidence of lung cancer has gone up dramatically whereas the incidence of lung

cancer in non-smokers has not increased in about four decades that's completely inconsistent with what the EPA is EPA is saying right now while the organs you could be turned the other way the risk to pass the smokers has been less over the years because since 1973 has been about a 30% drop in two percent of people who smoke regardless whether they are rising or whether they're decreasing there is a risk we've been able to characterize that risk

we've been able to use it to extrapolate to how many people that really affects and at least the EPA numbers would have us to believe that that number is somewhere near four thousand people per year the epa's final ruling on passive smoke will have no effect on regulation but could influence public policy what it will do is add to the evidence that the US Congress State legislatures business industry people in the public Arena you

lies to further provide protections to the American public they're now working with a known carcinogen rather than something that the tobacco industry has said is always it irritates people maybe they don't like the smell but it doesn't harm them we now have firm evidence that it's a carcinogen and that's a pretty frightening thing to tell the American public that something that is always been a matter of politeness

for example would you please put your cigarette out they've never thought that that cigarette could give them cancer it's only at the state and local levels where Clean Indoor Air laws have been passed 45 States and the district have and 480 cities and Counties have passed smoking restrictions many in those five states Alabama North Carolina Tennessee Louisiana and Missouri who have no law surprisingly American businesses have not waited for federal government regulation major

it says are Banning smoking in the workplace a move applauded by secretary Sullivan corporations I believe are increasingly understanding that they have a role to play in promoting a healthy work environment and one of the aspects of that is having a smoke-free environment we also know that our Business Leaders understand that the costs incurred by employees who smoke a much greater than non-smoking employees

he's worker productivity absenteeism increased costs for insurance Healthcare disability life increased energy costs because of the ventilation that's why a lot of companies are going totally smoke-free because they have to use a lot of energy to bring in the kind of ventilation that they need for requirements that that they have under certain regulations for buildings

fire protection also majority of the companies and work places and organizations are now computerized we've got a lot of modern technical equipment that is very sensitive to cigarette smoke Tim is says while some businesses have banned smoking others have restricted smoking setting aside designated smoking areas in the belief the building's ventilation system would clean the air pathologist dr. Ross has

learned people may be misled there is a notion that by putting a filter in the air system that tobacco smoke is filtered out that's just not so today's technology does not make it technologically feasible or even economically practical to try to filter out tobacco smoke in the ventilator in the air conditioning system or air handling units of the buildings for some employers the problem wasn't the ventilation system but the lack of space available for a designated smoking room and for some smokers

Breaking the Habit became more important as more public places enacted smoking restrictions for example in Minnesota a Clean Indoor Air State smoking is prohibited anywhere here in the arena where the Minnesota Timberwolves play Bob Stein says the owners have gone one step further by banning all tobacco advertising a move that will eventually cost millions of dollars in Lost Revenue traditionally cigarette advertising is the second-highest

advertising source for professional sports teams or as an arena building so they knew that they were going to be taking a financial loss to do it but there's belt we're not trying to make anyone else's decision but for us it was the right thing to do passive smoke causes lung cancer heart disease it in dangers children's lives yet there is no Federal Regulation of tobacco maintain that if we are serious

about our efforts to improve the health of our citizens in so many ways then we have to recognize and take action against those products that impair our health and among those tobacco use is number one
